pdgm.pdgmnote: Heine1975 p. 50
Heine1975 p. 45. These are the same for both affirmative and negative
Heine1975 p. 41
Heine1975 pp. 56f. Preceded by locative preposition ou. Sentences are glossed “be in Nairobi”.

Heine1975 pp. 57f. –lo’o “differs from other verbs in that it does not distinguish personal suffices. The prlural suffx is for both indefinite and definite aspect –ni. Past and Perfect markers are ee- and ene- rather than aa- and na-,respectively
Heine1975 p. 37
Heine1975 pp 46-50.
Heine1975 pp. 56f. Preceded by locative preposition ou. Sentences are glossed “be in Nairobi”.

Heine1975 pp. 57f. –lo’o “differs from other verbs in that it does not distinguish personal suffices. The prlural suffx is for both indefinite and definite aspect –ni. Past and Perfect markers are ee- and ene- rather than aa- and na-,respectively
Heine1975 pp 46-50.

Heine1975 pp. 51-54. “If the verb is preceded by constituents other than the subject,then it takes a prefix me- or ke-. Such pre-verbal constituents may be conjunctions,intrerrogative words,or object nouns. … The presence of me- usually implies a progressive action
Heine1975 pp 46-50.
Heine1975 pp 46-50.
Heine1975 pp. 54f. “Instead of ke,two series of pronoun-sensitive copula forms are optionally used”:copForm A is used of the cop is followed by a noun or numeral,B if followed by adj.
Heine1975 pp 46-50.
Heine1975 pp 46-50.

Heine1975 pp. 51-54. “If the verb is preceded by constituents other than the subject,then it takes a prefix me- or ke-. Such pre-verbal constituents may be conjunctions,intrerrogative words,or object nouns. … The presence of me- usually implies a progressive action

Heine1975 pp. 57f. –lo’o “differs from other verbs in that it does not distinguish personal suffices. The prlural suffx is for both indefinite and definite aspect –ni. Past and Perfect markers are ee- and ene- rather than aa- and na-,respectively
Heine1975 p.46,49. General structure is:NEG/TAM+Subj(+Obj) Verb+Subj (Obj). NEG is n’ala in perfect,otherwise ŋe-

Heine1975 pp. 45,48. On formSets:“It seems hardly possible to generalize on the token of these suffixes as almost every verb as a set of its own.” These are not distinguished in the negative.
